scene-body.stagedir: Enter young LUCIUS, and LAVINIA running after him, and the boy flies from her, with books under his arm. Then enter TITUS and MARCUS

speech.speaker: Young LUCIUS
speech.line: Help, grandsire, help! my aunt Lavinia
Follows me every where, I know not why:
Good uncle Marcus, see how swift she comes.
Alas, sweet aunt, I know not what you mean.

speech.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: Stand by me, Lucius; do not fear thine aunt.

speech.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: She loves thee, boy, too well to do thee harm.

speech.speaker: Young LUCIUS
speech.line: Ay, when my father was in Rome she did.

speech.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: What means my niece Lavinia by these signs?

speech.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: Fear her not, Lucius: somewhat doth she mean:
See, Lucius, see how much she makes of thee:
Somewhither would she have thee go with her.
Ah, boy, Cornelia never with more care
Read to her sons than she hath read to thee
Sweet poetry and Tully's Orator.

speech.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: Canst thou not guess wherefore she plies thee thus?

speech.speaker: Young LUCIUS
speech.line: My lord, I know not, I, nor can I guess,
Unless some fit or frenzy do possess her:
For I have heard my grandsire say full oft,
Extremity of griefs would make men mad;
And I have read that Hecuba of Troy
Ran mad through sorrow: that made me to fear;
Although, my lord, I know my noble aunt
Loves me as dear as e'er my mother did,
And would not, but in fury, fright my youth:
Which made me down to throw my books, and fly--
Causeless, perhaps. But pardon me, sweet aunt:
And, madam, if my uncle Marcus go,
I will most willingly attend your ladyship.

speech.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: Lucius, I will.

scene-body.stagedir: LAVINIA turns over with her stumps the books which LUCIUS has let fall

speech.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: How now, Lavinia! Marcus, what means this?
Some book there is that she desires to see.
Which is it, girl, of these? Open them, boy.
But thou art deeper read, and better skill'd
Come, and take choice of all my library,
And so beguile thy sorrow, till the heavens
Reveal the damn'd contriver of this deed.
Why lifts she up her arms in sequence thus?

speech.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: I think she means that there was more than one
Confederate in the fact: ay, more there was;
Or else to heaven she heaves them for revenge.

speech.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: Lucius, what book is that she tosseth so?

speech.speaker: Young LUCIUS
speech.line: Grandsire, 'tis Ovid's Metamorphoses;
My mother gave it me.

speech.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: For love of her that's gone,
Perhaps she cull'd it from among the rest.

speech.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: Soft! see how busily she turns the leaves!
What would she find? Lavinia, shall I read?
This is the tragic tale of Philomel,
And treats of Tereus' treason and his rape:
And rape, I fear, was root of thine annoy.

speech.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: See, brother, see; note how she quotes the leaves.

speech.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: Lavinia, wert thou thus surprised, sweet girl,
Ravish'd and wrong'd, as Philomela was,
Forced in the ruthless, vast, and gloomy woods? See, see!
Ay, such a place there is, where we did hunt--
O, had we never, never hunted there!--
Pattern'd by that the poet here describes,
By nature made for murders and for rapes.

speech.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: O, why should nature build so foul a den,
Unless the gods delight in tragedies?

speech.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: Give signs, sweet girl, for here are none
but friends,
What Roman lord it was durst do the deed:
Or slunk not Saturnine, as Tarquin erst,
That left the camp to sin in Lucrece' bed?

speech.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: Sit down, sweet niece: brother, sit down by me.
Apollo, Pallas, Jove, or Mercury,
Inspire me, that I may this treason find!
My lord, look here: look here, Lavinia:
This sandy plot is plain; guide, if thou canst
This after me, when I have writ my name
Without the help of any hand at all.
speech.stagedir: He writes his name with his staff, and guides it with feet and mouth
speech.line: Cursed be that heart that forced us to this shift!
Write thou good niece; and here display, at last,
What God will have discover'd for revenge;
Heaven guide thy pen to print thy sorrows plain,
That we may know the traitors and the truth!

scene-body.stagedir: She takes the staff in her mouth, and guides it with her stumps, and writes

speech.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: O, do ye read, my lord, what she hath writ?
'Stuprum. Chiron. Demetrius.'

speech.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: What, what! the lustful sons of Tamora
Performers of this heinous, bloody deed?

speech.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: Magni Dominator poli,
Tam lentus audis scelera? tam lentus vides?

speech.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: O, calm thee, gentle lord; although I know
There is enough written upon this earth
To stir a mutiny in the mildest thoughts
And arm the minds of infants to exclaims.
My lord, kneel down with me; Lavinia, kneel;
And kneel, sweet boy, the Roman Hector's hope;
And swear with me, as, with the woful fere
And father of that chaste dishonour'd dame,
Lord Junius Brutus sware for Lucrece' rape,
That we will prosecute by good advice
Mortal revenge upon these traitorous Goths,
And see their blood, or die with this reproach.

speech.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: 'Tis sure enough, an you knew how.
But if you hunt these bear-whelps, then beware:
The dam will wake; and, if she wind you once,
She's with the lion deeply still in league,
And lulls him whilst she playeth on her back,
And when he sleeps will she do what she list.
You are a young huntsman, Marcus; let it alone;
And, come, I will go get a leaf of brass,
And with a gad of steel will write these words,
And lay it by: the angry northern wind
Will blow these sands, like Sibyl's leaves, abroad,
And where's your lesson, then? Boy, what say you?

speech.speaker: Young LUCIUS
speech.line: I say, my lord, that if I were a man,
Their mother's bed-chamber should not be safe
For these bad bondmen to the yoke of Rome.

speech.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: Ay, that's my boy! thy father hath full oft
For his ungrateful country done the like.

speech.speaker: Young LUCIUS
speech.line: And, uncle, so will I, an if I live.

speech.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: Come, go with me into mine armoury;
Lucius, I'll fit thee; and withal, my boy,
Shalt carry from me to the empress' sons
Presents that I intend to send them both:
Come, come; thou'lt do thy message, wilt thou not?

speech.speaker: Young LUCIUS
speech.line: Ay, with my dagger in their bosoms, grandsire.

speech.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: No, boy, not so; I'll teach thee another course.
Lavinia, come. Marcus, look to my house:
Lucius and I'll go brave it at the court:
Ay, marry, will we, sir; and we'll be waited on.

scene-body.stagedir: Exeunt TITUS, LAVINIA, and Young LUCIUS

speech.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: O heavens, can you hear a good man groan,
And not relent, or not compassion him?
Marcus, attend him in his ecstasy,
That hath more scars of sorrow in his heart
Than foemen's marks upon his batter'd shield;
But yet so just that he will not revenge.
Revenge, ye heavens, for old Andronicus!

scene.title: SCENE II. The same. A room in the palace.

scene-body.stagedir: Enter, from one side, AARON, DEMETRIUS, and CHIRON; from the other side, Young LUCIUS, and an Attendant, with a bundle of weapons, and verses writ upon them

speech.speaker: CHIRON
speech.line: Demetrius, here's the son of Lucius;
He hath some message to deliver us.

speech.speaker: AARON
speech.line: Ay, some mad message from his mad grandfather.

speech.speaker: Young LUCIUS
speech.line: My lords, with all the humbleness I may,
I greet your honours from Andronicus.
And pray the Roman gods confound you both!

speech.speaker: DEMETRIUS
speech.line: Gramercy, lovely Lucius: what's the news?

speech.speaker: Young LUCIUS
speech.line: Aside That you are both decipher'd, that's the news,
For villains mark'd with rape.--May it please you,
My grandsire, well advised, hath sent by me
The goodliest weapons of his armoury
To gratify your honourable youth,
The hope of Rome; for so he bade me say;
And so I do, and with his gifts present
Your lordships, that, whenever you have need,
You may be armed and appointed well:
And so I leave you both:
like bloody villains.

speech.speaker: DEMETRIUS
speech.line: What's here? A scroll; and written round about?
Let's see;
'Integer vitae, scelerisque purus,
Non eget Mauri jaculis, nec arcu.'

speech.speaker: CHIRON
speech.line: O, 'tis a verse in Horace; I know it well:
I read it in the grammar long ago.

speech.speaker: AARON
speech.line: Ay, just; a verse in Horace; right, you have it.
Now, what a thing it is to be an ass!
Here's no sound jest! the old man hath found their guilt;
And sends them weapons wrapped about with lines,
That wound, beyond their feeling, to the quick.
But were our witty empress well afoot,
She would applaud Andronicus' conceit:
But let her rest in her unrest awhile.
And now, young lords, was't not a happy star
Led us to Rome, strangers, and more than so,
Captives, to be advanced to this height?
It did me good, before the palace gate
To brave the tribune in his brother's hearing.

speech.speaker: DEMETRIUS
speech.line: But me more good, to see so great a lord
Basely insinuate and send us gifts.

speech.speaker: AARON
speech.line: Had he not reason, Lord Demetrius?
Did you not use his daughter very friendly?

speech.speaker: DEMETRIUS
speech.line: I would we had a thousand Roman dames
At such a bay, by turn to serve our lust.

speech.speaker: CHIRON
speech.line: A charitable wish and full of love.

speech.speaker: AARON
speech.line: Here lacks but your mother for to say amen.

speech.speaker: CHIRON
speech.line: And that would she for twenty thousand more.

speech.speaker: DEMETRIUS
speech.line: Come, let us go; and pray to all the gods
For our beloved mother in her pains.

speech.speaker: AARON
speech.line: Aside Pray to the devils; the gods have given us over.

speech.speaker: DEMETRIUS
speech.line: Why do the emperor's trumpets flourish thus?

speech.speaker: CHIRON
speech.line: Belike, for joy the emperor hath a son.

speech.speaker: DEMETRIUS
speech.line: Soft! who comes here?

scene-body.stagedir: Enter a Nurse, with a blackamoor Child in her arms

speech.speaker: Nurse
speech.line: Good morrow, lords:
O, tell me, did you see Aaron the Moor?

speech.speaker: AARON
speech.line: Well, more or less, or ne'er a whit at all,
Here Aaron is; and what with Aaron now?

speech.speaker: Nurse
speech.line: O gentle Aaron, we are all undone!
Now help, or woe betide thee evermore!

speech.speaker: AARON
speech.line: Why, what a caterwauling dost thou keep!
What dost thou wrap and fumble in thine arms?

speech.speaker: Nurse
speech.line: O, that which I would hide from heaven's eye,
Our empress' shame, and stately Rome's disgrace!
She is deliver'd, lords; she is deliver'd.

speech.speaker: AARON
speech.line: To whom?

speech.speaker: Nurse
speech.line: I mean, she is brought a-bed.

speech.speaker: AARON
speech.line: Well, God give her good rest! What hath he sent her?

speech.speaker: Nurse
speech.line: A devil.

speech.speaker: AARON
speech.line: Why, then she is the devil's dam; a joyful issue.

speech.speaker: Nurse
speech.line: A joyless, dismal, black, and sorrowful issue:
Here is the babe, as loathsome as a toad
Amongst the fairest breeders of our clime:
The empress sends it thee, thy stamp, thy seal,
And bids thee christen it with thy dagger's point.

speech.speaker: AARON
speech.line: 'Zounds, ye whore! is black so base a hue?
Sweet blowse, you are a beauteous blossom, sure.

speech.speaker: DEMETRIUS
speech.line: Villain, what hast thou done?

speech.speaker: AARON
speech.line: That which thou canst not undo.

speech.speaker: CHIRON
speech.line: Thou hast undone our mother.

speech.speaker: AARON
speech.line: Villain, I have done thy mother.

speech.speaker: DEMETRIUS
speech.line: And therein, hellish dog, thou hast undone.
Woe to her chance, and damn'd her loathed choice!
Accursed the offspring of so foul a fiend!

speech.speaker: CHIRON
speech.line: It shall not live.

speech.speaker: AARON
speech.line: It shall not die.

speech.speaker: Nurse
speech.line: Aaron, it must; the mother wills it so.

speech.speaker: AARON
speech.line: What, must it, nurse? then let no man but I
Do execution on my flesh and blood.

speech.speaker: DEMETRIUS
speech.line: I'll broach the tadpole on my rapier's point:
Nurse, give it me; my sword shall soon dispatch it.

speech.speaker: AARON
speech.line: Sooner this sword shall plough thy bowels up.
speech.stagedir: Takes the Child from the Nurse, and draws
speech.line: Stay, murderous villains! will you kill your brother?
Now, by the burning tapers of the sky,
That shone so brightly when this boy was got,
He dies upon my scimitar's sharp point
That touches this my first-born son and heir!
I tell you, younglings, not Enceladus,
With all his threatening band of Typhon's brood,
Nor great Alcides, nor the god of war,
Shall seize this prey out of his father's hands.
What, what, ye sanguine, shallow-hearted boys!
Ye white-limed walls! ye alehouse painted signs!
Coal-black is better than another hue,
In that it scorns to bear another hue;
For all the water in the ocean
Can never turn the swan's black legs to white,
Although she lave them hourly in the flood.
Tell the empress from me, I am of age
To keep mine own, excuse it how she can.

speech.speaker: DEMETRIUS
speech.line: Wilt thou betray thy noble mistress thus?

speech.speaker: AARON
speech.line: My mistress is my mistress; this myself,
The vigour and the picture of my youth:
This before all the world do I prefer;
This maugre all the world will I keep safe,
Or some of you shall smoke for it in Rome.

speech.speaker: DEMETRIUS
speech.line: By this our mother is forever shamed.

speech.speaker: CHIRON
speech.line: Rome will despise her for this foul escape.

speech.speaker: Nurse
speech.line: The emperor, in his rage, will doom her death.

speech.speaker: CHIRON
speech.line: I blush to think upon this ignomy.

speech.speaker: AARON
speech.line: Why, there's the privilege your beauty bears:
Fie, treacherous hue, that will betray with blushing
The close enacts and counsels of the heart!
Here's a young lad framed of another leer:
Look, how the black slave smiles upon the father,
As who should say 'Old lad, I am thine own.'
He is your brother, lords, sensibly fed
Of that self-blood that first gave life to you,
And from that womb where you imprison'd were
He is enfranchised and come to light:
Nay, he is your brother by the surer side,
Although my seal be stamped in his face.

speech.speaker: Nurse
speech.line: Aaron, what shall I say unto the empress?

speech.speaker: DEMETRIUS
speech.line: Advise thee, Aaron, what is to be done,
And we will all subscribe to thy advice:
Save thou the child, so we may all be safe.

speech.speaker: AARON
speech.line: Then sit we down, and let us all consult.
My son and I will have the wind of you:
Keep there: now talk at pleasure of your safety.

speech.speaker: DEMETRIUS
speech.line: How many women saw this child of his?

speech.speaker: AARON
speech.line: Why, so, brave lords! when we join in league,
I am a lamb: but if you brave the Moor,
The chafed boar, the mountain lioness,
The ocean swells not so as Aaron storms.
But say, again; how many saw the child?

speech.speaker: Nurse
speech.line: Cornelia the midwife and myself;
And no one else but the deliver'd empress.

speech.speaker: AARON
speech.line: The empress, the midwife, and yourself:
Two may keep counsel when the third's away:
Go to the empress, tell her this I said.
Weke, weke! so cries a pig prepared to the spit.

speech.speaker: DEMETRIUS
speech.line: What mean'st thou, Aaron? wherefore didst thou this?

speech.speaker: AARON
speech.line: O Lord, sir, 'tis a deed of policy:
Shall she live to betray this guilt of ours,
A long-tongued babbling gossip? no, lords, no:
And now be it known to you my full intent.
Not far, one Muli lives, my countryman;
His wife but yesternight was brought to bed;
His child is like to her, fair as you are:
Go pack with him, and give the mother gold,
And tell them both the circumstance of all;
And how by this their child shall be advanced,
And be received for the emperor's heir,
And substituted in the place of mine,
To calm this tempest whirling in the court;
And let the emperor dandle him for his own.
Hark ye, lords; ye see I have given her physic,
And you must needs bestow her funeral;
The fields are near, and you are gallant grooms:
This done, see that you take no longer days,
But send the midwife presently to me.
The midwife and the nurse well made away,
Then let the ladies tattle what they please.

speech.speaker: CHIRON
speech.line: Aaron, I see thou wilt not trust the air
With secrets.

speech.speaker: DEMETRIUS
speech.line: For this care of Tamora,
Herself and hers are highly bound to thee.

scene-body.stagedir: Exeunt DEMETRIUS and CHIRON bearing off the Nurse's body

speech.speaker: AARON
speech.line: Now to the Goths, as swift as swallow flies;
There to dispose this treasure in mine arms,
And secretly to greet the empress' friends.
Come on, you thick lipp'd slave, I'll bear you hence;
For it is you that puts us to our shifts:
I'll make you feed on berries and on roots,
And feed on curds and whey, and suck the goat,
And cabin in a cave, and bring you up
To be a warrior, and command a camp.

scene.title: SCENE III. The same. A public place.

scene-body.stagedir: Enter TITUS, bearing arrows with letters at the ends of them; with him, MARCUS, Young LUCIUS, PUBLIUS, SEMPRONIUS, CAIUS, and other Gentlemen, with bows

speech.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: Come, Marcus; come, kinsmen; this is the way.
Sir boy, now let me see your archery;
Look ye draw home enough, and 'tis there straight.
Terras Astraea reliquit:
Be you remember'd, Marcus, she's gone, she's fled.
Sirs, take you to your tools. You, cousins, shall
Go sound the ocean, and cast your nets;
Happily you may catch her in the sea;
Yet there's as little justice as at land:
No; Publius and Sempronius, you must do it;
'Tis you must dig with mattock and with spade,
And pierce the inmost centre of the earth:
Then, when you come to Pluto's region,
I pray you, deliver him this petition;
Tell him, it is for justice and for aid,
And that it comes from old Andronicus,
Shaken with sorrows in ungrateful Rome.
Ah, Rome! Well, well; I made thee miserable
What time I threw the people's suffrages
On him that thus doth tyrannize o'er me.
Go, get you gone; and pray be careful all,
And leave you not a man-of-war unsearch'd:
This wicked emperor may have shipp'd her hence;
And, kinsmen, then we may go pipe for justice.

speech.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: O Publius, is not this a heavy case,
To see thy noble uncle thus distract?

speech.speaker: PUBLIUS
speech.line: Therefore, my lord, it highly us concerns
By day and night to attend him carefully,
And feed his humour kindly as we may,
Till time beget some careful remedy.

speech.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: Kinsmen, his sorrows are past remedy.
Join with the Goths; and with revengeful war
Take wreak on Rome for this ingratitude,
And vengeance on the traitor Saturnine.

speech.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: Publius, how now! how now, my masters!
What, have you met with her?

speech.speaker: PUBLIUS
speech.line: No, my good lord; but Pluto sends you word,
If you will have Revenge from hell, you shall:
Marry, for Justice, she is so employ'd,
He thinks, with Jove in heaven, or somewhere else,
So that perforce you must needs stay a time.

speech.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: He doth me wrong to feed me with delays.
I'll dive into the burning lake below,
And pull her out of Acheron by the heels.
Marcus, we are but shrubs, no cedars we
No big-boned men framed of the Cyclops' size;
But metal, Marcus, steel to the very back,
Yet wrung with wrongs more than our backs can bear:
And, sith there's no justice in earth nor hell,
We will solicit heaven and move the gods
To send down Justice for to wreak our wrongs.
Come, to this gear. You are a good archer, Marcus;
'Ad Jovem,' that's for you: here, 'Ad Apollinem:'
'Ad Martem,' that's for myself:
Here, boy, to Pallas: here, to Mercury:
To Saturn, Caius, not to Saturnine;
You were as good to shoot against the wind.
To it, boy! Marcus, loose when I bid.
Of my word, I have written to effect;
There's not a god left unsolicited.

speech.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: Kinsmen, shoot all your shafts into the court:
We will afflict the emperor in his pride.

speech.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: Now, masters, draw.
O, well said, Lucius!
Good boy, in Virgo's lap; give it Pallas.

speech.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: My lord, I aim a mile beyond the moon;
Your letter is with Jupiter by this.

speech.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: Ha, ha!
Publius, Publius, what hast thou done?
See, see, thou hast shot off one of Taurus' horns.

speech.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: This was the sport, my lord: when Publius shot,
The Bull, being gall'd, gave Aries such a knock
That down fell both the Ram's horns in the court;
And who should find them but the empress' villain?
She laugh'd, and told the Moor he should not choose
But give them to his master for a present.

speech.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: Why, there it goes: God give his lordship joy!
speech.stagedir: Enter a Clown, with a basket, and two pigeons in it
speech.line: News, news from heaven! Marcus, the post is come.
Sirrah, what tidings? have you any letters?
Shall I have justice? what says Jupiter?

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: O, the gibbet-maker! he says that he hath taken
them down again, for the man must not be hanged till
the next week.

speech.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: But what says Jupiter, I ask thee?

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: Alas, sir, I know not Jupiter; I never drank with him
in all my life.

speech.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: Why, villain, art not thou the carrier?

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: Ay, of my pigeons, sir; nothing else.

speech.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: Why, didst thou not come from heaven?

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: From heaven! alas, sir, I never came there God
forbid I should be so bold to press to heaven in my
young days. Why, I am going with my pigeons to the
tribunal plebs, to take up a matter of brawl
betwixt my uncle and one of the emperial's men.

speech.speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: Why, sir, that is as fit as can be to serve for
your oration; and let him deliver the pigeons to
the emperor from you.

speech.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: Tell me, can you deliver an oration to the emperor
with a grace?

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: Nay, truly, sir, I could never say grace in all my life.

speech.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: Sirrah, come hither: make no more ado,
But give your pigeons to the emperor:
By me thou shalt have justice at his hands.
Hold, hold; meanwhile here's money for thy charges.
Give me pen and ink. Sirrah, can you with a grace
deliver a supplication?

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: Ay, sir.

speech.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: Then here is a supplication for you. And when you
come to him, at the first approach you must kneel,
then kiss his foot, then deliver up your pigeons, and
then look for your reward. I'll be at hand, sir; see
you do it bravely.

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: I warrant you, sir, let me alone.

speech.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: Sirrah, hast thou a knife? come, let me see it.
Here, Marcus, fold it in the oration;
For thou hast made it like an humble suppliant.
And when thou hast given it the emperor,
Knock at my door, and tell me what he says.

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: God be with you, sir; I will.

speech.speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
speech.line: Come, Marcus, let us go. Publius, follow me.

scene.title: SCENE IV. The same. Before the palace.

scene-body.stagedir: Enter SATURNINUS, TAMORA, DEMETRIUS, CHIRON, Lords, and others; SATURNINUS with the arrows in his hand that TITUS shot

speech.speaker: SATURNINUS
speech.line: Why, lords, what wrongs are these! was ever seen
An emperor in Rome thus overborne,
Troubled, confronted thus; and, for the extent
Of egal justice, used in such contempt?
My lords, you know, as know the mightful gods,
However these disturbers of our peace
Buz in the people's ears, there nought hath pass'd,
But even with law, against the willful sons
Of old Andronicus. And what an if
His sorrows have so overwhelm'd his wits,
Shall we be thus afflicted in his wreaks,
His fits, his frenzy, and his bitterness?
And now he writes to heaven for his redress:
See, here's to Jove, and this to Mercury;
This to Apollo; this to the god of war;
Sweet scrolls to fly about the streets of Rome!
What's this but libelling against the senate,
And blazoning our injustice every where?
A goodly humour, is it not, my lords?
As who would say, in Rome no justice were.
But if I live, his feigned ecstasies
Shall be no shelter to these outrages:
But he and his shall know that justice lives
In Saturninus' health, whom, if she sleep,
He'll so awake as she in fury shall
Cut off the proud'st conspirator that lives.

speech.speaker: TAMORA
speech.line: My gracious lord, my lovely Saturnine,
Lord of my life, commander of my thoughts,
Calm thee, and bear the faults of Titus' age,
The effects of sorrow for his valiant sons,
Whose loss hath pierced him deep and scarr'd his heart;
And rather comfort his distressed plight
Than prosecute the meanest or the best
For these contempts.
Why, thus it shall become
High-witted Tamora to gloze with all:
But, Titus, I have touched thee to the quick,
Thy life-blood out: if Aaron now be wise,
Then is all safe, the anchor's in the port.
How now, good fellow! wouldst thou speak with us?

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: Yea, forsooth, an your mistership be emperial.

speech.speaker: TAMORA
speech.line: Empress I am, but yonder sits the emperor.

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: 'Tis he. God and Saint Stephen give you good den:
I have brought you a letter and a couple of pigeons here.

speech.speaker: SATURNINUS
speech.line: Go, take him away, and hang him presently.

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: How much money must I have?

speech.speaker: TAMORA
speech.line: Come, sirrah, you must be hanged.

speech.speaker: Clown
speech.line: Hanged! by'r lady, then I have brought up a neck to
a fair end.

speech.speaker: SATURNINUS
speech.line: Despiteful and intolerable wrongs!
Shall I endure this monstrous villany?
I know from whence this same device proceeds:
May this be borne?--as if his traitorous sons,
That died by law for murder of our brother,
Have by my means been butcher'd wrongfully!
Go, drag the villain hither by the hair;
Nor age nor honour shall shape privilege:
For this proud mock I'll be thy slaughterman;
Sly frantic wretch, that holp'st to make me great,
In hope thyself should govern Rome and me.
What news with thee, AEmilius?

speech.speaker: AEMILIUS
speech.line: Arm, arm, my lord;--Rome never had more cause.
The Goths have gather'd head; and with a power
high-resolved men, bent to the spoil,
They hither march amain, under conduct
Of Lucius, son to old Andronicus;
Who threats, in course of this revenge, to do
As much as ever Coriolanus did.

speech.speaker: SATURNINUS
speech.line: Is warlike Lucius general of the Goths?
These tidings nip me, and I hang the head
As flowers with frost or grass beat down with storms:
Ay, now begin our sorrows to approach:
'Tis he the common people love so much;
Myself hath often over-heard them say,
When I have walked like a private man,
That Lucius' banishment was wrongfully,
And they have wish'd that Lucius were their emperor.

speech.speaker: TAMORA
speech.line: Why should you fear? is not your city strong?

speech.speaker: SATURNINUS
speech.line: Ay, but the citizens favor Lucius,
And will revolt from me to succor him.

speech.speaker: TAMORA
speech.line: King, be thy thoughts imperious, like thy name.
Is the sun dimm'd, that gnats do fly in it?
The eagle suffers little birds to sing,
And is not careful what they mean thereby,
Knowing that with the shadow of his wings
He can at pleasure stint their melody:
Even so mayst thou the giddy men of Rome.
Then cheer thy spirit : for know, thou emperor,
I will enchant the old Andronicus
With words more sweet, and yet more dangerous,
Than baits to fish, or honey-stalks to sheep,
When as the one is wounded with the bait,
The other rotted with delicious feed.

speech.speaker: SATURNINUS
speech.line: But he will not entreat his son for us.

speech.speaker: TAMORA
speech.line: If Tamora entreat him, then he will:
For I can smooth and fill his aged ear
With golden promises; that, were his heart
Almost impregnable, his old ears deaf,
Yet should both ear and heart obey my tongue.
Go thou before, be our ambassador:
Say that the emperor requests a parley
Of warlike Lucius, and appoint the meeting
Even at his father's house, the old Andronicus.

speech.speaker: SATURNINUS
speech.line: AEmilius, do this message honourably:
And if he stand on hostage for his safety,
Bid him demand what pledge will please him best.

speech.speaker: AEMILIUS
speech.line: Your bidding shall I do effectually.

speech.speaker: TAMORA
speech.line: Now will I to that old Andronicus;
And temper him with all the art I have,
To pluck proud Lucius from the warlike Goths.
And now, sweet emperor, be blithe again,
And bury all thy fear in my devices.

speech.speaker: SATURNINUS
speech.line: Then go successantly, and plead to him.
